Stem: The students in Mr. Johnson's class conducted an experiment to study shadow patterns throughout the day. Time of Day Shadow Length (meters) Shadow Direction 7:00 a.m. 12 Westward 9:00 a.m. 7 Westward 11:00 a.m. 3 Northward 1:00 p.m. 4 Eastward 3:00 p.m. 8 Eastward 5:00 p.m. ? Eastward If the students were to return at 5:00 p.m. to complete their data collection, which of the following would most likely be the shadow length and why?
Choices: A) 3 meters, because shadows are always shortest in the late afternoon when the Sun is still high in the sky., B) 7 meters, because the shadow at 5:00 p.m. would be the same length as at 9:00 a.m. when the Sun is at the same height but on the opposite side of the sky., C) 10 meters, because the rate of shadow lengthening from 11:00 a.m. to 3:00 p.m. suggests the shadow would continue to lengthen but not exceed the morning length., D) 13 meters, because shadows get progressively longer throughout the afternoon as the Sun moves toward the western horizon. The table below shows the time of day in different cities around the world at the same moment.
